climbs.name: Koedt-Rowat (Southwest Face, South Dihedral)
climbs.fa: Peter Koedt and Peter Rowat, August 1974

content.description:
Scramble up into the grassy bowl at the base of the right side of the southwest face. Keep scrambling as high as you can before roping up. A long easy pitch with a chimney (5.7ish) leads to a niche. Climb up the left side of a curving flake (5.9, 3" to 4") or up the flake itself and then left across the face above with more difficulty (10 b/c). Climb up another long easy pitch (5.7) to the base of a steep left-facing corner. Awesome laybacking, finger jamming Â and stemming up the corner (5.9 or 10a, *****) leads to a traverse left to belay. One more easy pitch (5.6) leads to the top out on the upper west ridge just below the summit tower.



See TOPO. Right side of SW face.

Nice to have doubles from finger size to fists. One full set of nuts, one full set of cams, and some extra Tri Cams worked really well bitd.

climbs.name: SW Face to SE Ridge (Route 3 Variation)
climbs.fa: SW Face: Tom Chamberlin, Pete Renz 1969; SE Ridge: Eric Rance, John Wurflinger Aug 1969

content.description:
As described, a link-up of two separate routes. Start in the grassy bowl below the SW face as for the Koedt-Rowat but go as far right as possible and quest up nebulous rock for several pitches towards the ridge crest (up to 5.7 if on route, easily 5.8 or harder if seeking out funner moves and cleaner rock). Cross the ridge below the Black Tower and cross over a gully via a long rightwards traverse. Continue up the right side of the gully via endless 4th class rock all the way to the summit. A long day on easy solid rock.



Start below the Koedt-Rowat and go right

A light rack to 3" will be fine.

climbs.name: West Ridge
climbs.fa: Kim (Richard) Deane, John Oswald, Mike Stewart, Bud Stovel, Parker Williams Aug 31/1963

content.description:
Climb the gully between Trireme Wall and Gladsheim to the ridge crest (snow or boulders). Gain the ridge crest and continue up (lots of 4th) to the first crux. Continue via more 4th to the second crux, which leads to a chimney tunnel through the ridge from the south to the north side! Continue on again to where it gets easier. Walk to the base of the final summit tower and scramble to summit. Definitely somewhat more challenging on the cruxes than the NW Ridge of Sir Donald.



You're looking at it from Mulvey Lake.

When descending, plan on two rappels (30 m and 10 m) and a hell of a lot of 4th class downclimbing.

Light rack.
